With aApparent magnitudevisual magnitudeof −0.05, it is thelist of brightest starsfourth brightest starin thenight sky, after −1.46 magnitudeSirius, −0.86 magnitudeCanopus (star)Canopus, and −0.27 magnitudeAlpha Centauri. It is a relatively close star at only 36.7light-yearsfrom Earth, and, together withVegaand Sirius, one of the most luminous stars in theSun's neighborhood.

article.heading: Observational history
article.paragraph: As one of the brightest stars in the sky, Arcturus has been significant to observers since antiquity. In Mesopotamia, it was linked to the godEnlil, and also known as Shudun, "yoke",or SHU-PA of unknown derivation in theThree Stars EachBabylonian star cataloguesand laterMUL.APINaround 1100 BC.cite journalRogersJohn H.1998Origins of the Ancient Constellations: I. The Mesopotamian TraditionsJournal of the British Astronomical Association10819–281998JBAA..108....9R
Ptolemy described Arcturus assubrufa"slightly red", and it has a B-V color index of +1.23, roughly midway betweenPollux (star)Pollux(B-V +1.00) andAldebaran(B-V +1.54).

PrehistoricPolynesian navigationPolynesian navigatorsknew Arcturus asHklea, the "Star of Joy". Arcturus is thezenithstar of theHawaiian Islands. Using Hklea and other stars, the Polynesians launched their double-hulledcanoesfromTahitiand theMarquesas Islands. Traveling east and north they eventually crossed theequatorand reached thelatitudeat which Arcturus would appear directly overhead in the summernight sky. Knowing they had arrived at the exact latitude of the island chain, they sailed due west on thetrade windsto landfall. If Hklea could be kept directly overhead, they landed on the southeastern shores of theHawaii (island)Big IslandofHawaiiHawaii. For a return trip to Tahiti the navigators could useSirius, the zenith star of that island. Since 1976, thePolynesian Voyaging Society'sHokuleaHkleahas crossed the Pacific Ocean many times under navigators who have incorporated thiswayfindingtechnique in their non-instrument navigation.

The French mathematician and astronomerJean-Baptiste Morin (mathematician)Jean-Baptiste Morinobserved Arcturus in the daytime with a telescope (a first for any star other than the Sun andsupernovae) in 1635, and Arcturus has been seen at or just before sunset with the naked eye.

The margin of error is 0.54 milliarcseconds, translating to a margin of error ofConvert0.7pclyoffonflip.
Together withSpicaandDenebola(orRegulus, depending on the source), Arcturus is part of theSpring Triangleasterism, and by extension, also of theGreat Diamondafter factoring inCor Caroli.
article.heading: Visibility
article.paragraph: Arcturus has avisual magnitudeof −0.05, making it the brightest star north of thecelestial equator, and thelist of brightest starsfourth brightest starin thenight sky.cite bookThe Hundred Greatest StarsKaler, James B.2002Copernicus BooksNew York, New York0-387-95436-821However, Alpha Centauri is a bright binary star, whose unresolved components to the naked eye are both fainter than Arcturus. This makes Arcturus thelist of brightest starsthird brightest ''individual'' star, just ahead of Alpha Centauri A ( Cen A), whose visual magnitude is −0.01.cite bookFredSchaaf2008The Brightest Stars: Discovering the Universe Through the Sky's Most Brilliant Stars126–36John Wiley and SonsHoboken, New Jersey978-0-471-70410-2

Arcturus is visible from both Earth's hemispheres as it is located 19 north of thecelestial equator. The starculminationculminatesat midnight on 27 April, and at 9PM on June 10 being visible during the late northern spring or the southern autumn.Schaaf, p. 257.From thenorthern hemisphere, an easy way to find Arcturus is to follow the arc of the handle of theBig Dipper. By continuing in this path, one can findSpica, "Arc to Arcturus, then spike toSpica".

Eta Botis, or Muphrid, is only 3.3light-yearsdistant from Arcturus, and would have a visual magnitude 2.5, whereas an observer on the former system would find Arcturus as bright as Venus as seen from Earth.
article.heading: Properties
article.paragraph: File:Arcturus (optical).pngthumbright275 pxOptical image of Arcturus (DSS2 / MAST / STScI / NASA)Arcturus is astellar classificationtypeK0 IIIred giantstar. It is at least 110 times moreluminosityluminousthan theSunin visible light wavelengths, but this underestimates its strength as much of the light it gives off is in theinfrared; total (Bolometric correctionbolometric) power output is about 180 times that of the Sun. The lower output in visible light is due to a lowerLuminous efficacyefficacyas the star has a lowereffective temperaturesurface temperaturethan the Sun. With a near-infraredJ bandMagnitude (astronomy)magnitudeof 2.2, onlyBetelgeuse(2.9) andR Doradus(2.6) are brighter.

As the brightest K-typeGiant star#Red giantsgiantin the sky, it was the subject of anspectral atlasatlasof itsvisible spectrum, made fromphotographic platephotographicspectra taken with theReflecting telescope#Coudcoudspectrographof theHooker telescopeMt. Wilson 2.5m telescopepublished in 1968,cite bookGriffinR. E.GriffinR.A photometric atlas of the spectrum of Arcturus, λλ3600-8825ÅCambridge Philosophical SocietyCambridge19681968pmas.book.....Ga key reference work for stellar spectroscopy. Subsequent spectral atlasescite bookHinkleKennethWallaceLloydValentiJeffHarmerDianneVisible and Near Infrared Atlas of the Arcturus Spectrum 3727-9300 Å2000vnia.book.....H[[Astronomical Society of the Pacific]]San Francisco1-58381-037-42000cite bookHinkleKennethWallaceLloydLivingstonWilliam CharlesInfrared atlas of the Arcturus spectrum, 0.9-5.3 microns1995iaas.book.....HAstronomical Society of the PacificSan Francisco1995cite bookHinkleKennethWallaceLloydValentiJeffAyresThomasUltraviolet Atlas of the Arcturus Spectrum, 1150-3800 Å2005uaas.book.....HAstronomical Society of the PacificSan Francisco2005with greater wavelength coverage and superiorsignal-to-noise ratiomade with digital detectors have supplanted the older work, but the Arcturus spectrum remains an important standard for stellar spectroscopy.

The mass of Arcturus is hard to determine precisely, but may be slightly larger than that of the Sun (1.08 0.06 solar masses).Arcturus has been estimated to be around 6 billion to 8.5 billion years old,and has likely begun fusing helium into oxygen and carbon in its core. It will expand further after its helium supply is exhausted, slough off its outer shell and become a white dwarf inside a planetary nebula.
article.heading: Oscillations
article.paragraph: As one of the brightest stars in the sky, Arcturus has been the subject of a number of studies in the emerging field ofasteroseismology.

Belmonte and colleagues carried out a radial velocity (Doppler shift of spectral lines) study of the star in April and May 1988, which showed variability with a frequency of the order of a fewHertzmicrohertz, the highest peak corresponding to 4.3 Hz (2.7 days) with an amplitude of 60 ms1, with afrequency separationof ~5 Hz. They suggested that the most plausible explanation for the variability of Arcturus is stellar oscillations.cite journalBelmonte, J. A.; Jones, A. R.; Palle, P. L.; Roca Cortes, T.1990Acoustic oscillations in the K2 III star ArcturusAstrophysics and Space Science1691–277–840004-640X10.1007/BF006406891990Ap&SS.169...77B

It is believed that the surface of the star oscillates slightly, a common feature of red giant stars. In the case of Arcturus, this was an interesting discovery as it is known that the redder (more towards or within the M spectral class) a giant gets, the more variable it will be. Extreme cases likeMiraundergo large swings over hundreds of days; Arcturus is not very red and is a borderline case between variability and stability with its short period and tiny range.Citation neededApril 2012

article.heading: Kinematics
article.paragraph: Arcturus is notable for its highproper motion, twoMinute of arcarc secondsa year, greater than any first magnitude star other thanAlpha Centauri Centauri. It is moving rapidly (nowrap122 km/s) relative to the Solar System, and is now almost at its closest point to the Sun. Closest approach will happen in about 4,000 years, when the star will be a few hundredths of a light year closer to Earth than it is today. Arcturus is thought to be anold disk star, and appears to be moving with a group of 52 other such stars, known as theArcturus stream.cite webhttp://earthsky.org/brightest-stars/bright-orange-arcturus-use-the-big-dipper-to-find-itArcturus, orange star, cuts through galaxy’s disk[[EarthSky]]2011-05-182012-01-24Larry SessionsDeborah Byrd

In antiquity, Arcturus was closer to the centre of the constellation.cite journalRogersJohn H.1998Origins of the Ancient Constellations: II. The Mediterranean TraditionsJournal of the British Astronomical Association108279–891998JBAA..108...79R
article.heading: Possible planetary system
article.paragraph: Hipparcosalso suggested that Arcturus is abinary star, with the companion about twenty times dimmer than the primary and orbiting close enough to be at the very limits of our current ability to make it out. Recent results remain inconclusive, but do support the marginalHipparcosdetection of a binary companion.Cite journalT.VerhoelstP. J.4BordéG.PerrinL.DecinIs Arcturus a well-understood K giant?Astronomy & Astrophysics200543528910.1051/0004-6361:20042356ErikssonK.RidgwayS. T.SchullerP. A.TraubW. A.Millan-GabetR.LacasseM. G.WaelkensC.2005A&A...435..289Vastro-ph/0501669, and see references therein.

In 1993, radial velocity measurements ofAldebaran, Arcturus andPollux (star)Polluxshowed that Arcturus exhibited a long-period radial velocity oscillation, which could be interpreted as asubstellar companion. Thissubstellar objectwould be nearly 12 times the mass ofJupiterand be located roughly at the same orbital distance from Arcturus as the Earth is from the Sun, at 1.1 Astronomical Units. However, all three stars surveyed showed similar oscillations yielding similar companion masses, and the authors concluded that the variation was likely to be intrinsic to the star rather than due to the gravitational effect of a companion. So far no substellar companion has been confirmed.cite journal10.1086/173002Long-period radial velocity variations in three K giantsHatzes, A.Cochran, W.[[The Astrophysical Journal]]4131339–348August 19931993ApJ...413..339H

article.paragraph: File:Redgiants.svgthumbright200pxComparison between Arcturus, red supergiantAntares, and the Sun. The black circle is the size of the orbit of Mars.The name of the star derives fromAncient Greek(Arktouros) and means "Guardian of the Bear",, Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott,A Greek-English Lexicon, on Perseusultimately from (arktos), "bear", Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott,A Greek-English Lexicon, on Perseus+ (ouros), "watcher, guardian"., Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott,A Greek-English Lexicon, on PerseusIt has been known by this name since at least the time ofHesiod.This is a reference to its being the brightest star in the constellation Botes (of which it forms the left foot), which is next to the Greater and Lesser Bears,Ursa MajorandUrsa Minor.

article.heading: India
article.paragraph: In IndianAstrologyorJyotiaVedic AstrologyorSidereal astrologySidereal Astrology, Arcturus is called'Swati the StarSwati' which is a word meaning "very beneficent" derived from the languageSanskrit. It is theeponymousstar of one of thenakshatras(lunar mansions) ofHindu astrology.
article.heading: Inuit
article.paragraph: InInuit astronomy, Arcturus is called the Old Man (UttuqalualukinInuit) and The First Ones (SivulliikinInuit).citation neededJanuary 2015
TheMi'kmaqof eastern Canada saw Arcturus asKookoogwss, the owl.cite journalHagarStansbury1900The Celestial BearThe Journal of American Folklore134992–10353379910.2307/533799

article.paragraph: In Indonesia, Arcturus is calledBintang Biduk(star of boat).citation neededSeptember 2014
article.heading: Polynesia
article.paragraph: Arcturus had several names that described its significance to indigenousPolynesians. In theSociety Islands, Arcturus, calledAna-tahua-taata-metua-te-tupu-mavae("a pillar to stand by"), was one of the ten "pillars of the sky", bright stars that represented the ten heavens of theTahitianafterlife.sfnMakemson1941199InHawaii, the pattern of Botes was calledHoku-iwa, meaning "stars of the frigate bird". This constellation marked the path forHawaiiloaon his return to Hawaii from the South Pacific Ocean.sfnMakemson1941209The Hawaiians called ArcturusHoku-lea.sfnMakemson1941280It was equated to theTuamotuanconstellationTe Kiva, meaning "frigate-bird", which could either represent the figure of Botes or just Arcturus.sfnMakemson1941221However, Arcturus may instead be the Tuamotuan star calledTuru.sfnMakemson1941264The Hawaiian name for Arcturus as a single star was likelyHoku-lea, which means "star of gladness".sfnMakemson1941210In theMarquesas Islands, Arcturus was probably calledTau-touand was the star that ruled the month approximating January. TheMori peopleMaoriandMoriori peopleMorioricalled itTautoru, a variant of the Marquesan name and a name shared withOrion's Belt.sfnMakemson1941260
article.heading: Japan
article.paragraph: InJapan, Arcturus is calledMugi-boshi(), meaningstar of wheat.citation neededJanuary 2015
article.heading: 1933 World's Fair
article.paragraph: Arcturus achieved fame when its light was rumored to be the mechanism used to open theCentury of Progress1933 Chicago World's Fair. The star was chosen as it was thought that light from Arcturus had started its journey at about the time of theWorld's Columbian Expositionprevious Chicago World's Fairin 1893. The star is 36.7 light-yearsfromEarth, and the light started its journey in 1896.cite webCentury of Progress World's Fair, 1933-1934University of Illinois-ChicagoJanuary 2008http://collections.carli.illinois.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT2009-09-06
